title: 111_hr4539
content: The "Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010" is the short title of this Act. It addresses the treatment of foreign investments in United States real property. The "Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010" amends subsection (c) of section 897 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to define a United States real property interest as an interest in real property located in the United States or the Virgin Islands, including fee ownership, co-ownership, leaseholds, and options to acquire land or improvements. The Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010 expands the definition of real property to include movable walls and furnishings. Section 897(h) is amended to include special rules for certain investment entities regarding distributions related to gains from sales of US real property. The Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010 expands the definition of real property to include movable walls and furnishings. Section 897(h) introduces special rules for qualified investment entities regarding distributions related to gains from sales of US real property. Liquidating distributions from such entities are treated as ordinary dividends. The Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010 expands the definition of real property to include movable walls and furnishings. Qualified investment entities, such as real estate investment trusts and regulated investment companies, are subject to special rules under Section 897 regarding distributions related to gains from sales of US real property. Liquidating distributions from these entities are treated as ordinary dividends. The Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010 broadens the definition of real property to include movable walls and furnishings. Special rules under Section 897 apply to distributions related to gains from US real property sales by qualified investment entities like real estate investment trusts. Liquidating distributions from these entities are treated as ordinary dividends. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to reflect these changes. The amendments made by the Real Estate Revitalization Act of 2010 broaden the definition of real property to include movable walls and furnishings. Changes are made to Section 1445(e) and Section 6039C(d) of the tax code regarding interests in real property located in the United States and the Virgin Islands. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
